definition: **noun / packaging term.** A **premium jacket style where the printed slick is glued ('tipped-on') to a separate cardboard core** — the vintage U.S. norm in the 1950s-70s, revived by audiophile labels. The construction involves printing artwork on thin coated paper stock, then adhering it to thicker chipboard backing, creating a tactile two-layer feel. This labor-intensive process dominated major-label releases during vinyl's golden age, delivering superior color reproduction and a luxurious hand-feel compared to modern direct-to-board printing. Blue Note, Prestige, and Columbia used tip-ons extensively for jazz and rock releases. The method fell out of favor in the late 1970s as cost-cutting measures pushed the industry toward single-layer jackets. Contemporary reissue labels like Music Matters, Analogue Productions, and Speakers Corner have revived tip-on construction as a premium feature, often paired with 180g vinyl and all-analog mastering. Collectors prize original tip-on pressings for their durability—the slick can be replaced if damaged—and authentic period aesthetics. Expect to pay 20-40% more for modern tip-on editions.
etymology: From printing terminology 'tip-in' or 'tip-on,' referring to the process of pasting one sheet onto another, adopted by record manufacturers in the early LP era (late 1940s).
